rice_dishes.thai_script: โจ๊ก
rice_dishes.description: Of Chinese origin, it is a rice congee with minced chicken or pork. Mixing an egg in with the congee is optional.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวกั๊นจิ๊น
rice_dishes.description: A dish of the Tai Yai (Shan people) of Myanmar and northern Thailand, it is rice that is mixed with pork blood and steamed inside a banana leaf. Khao kan chin is served with cucumber, onions and fried, dried chillies.[1]

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวขาหมู
rice_dishes.description: Steamed rice is served with sliced pig's trotters which has been simmered in soy sauce and five spice powder. It is always served with a sweet spicy dipping sauce, fresh bird's eye chillies and cloves of garlic on the side. Boiled egg and a clear broth on the side are optional.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวไข่เจียว
rice_dishes.description: A quick snack or breakfast, it is an omelet with white rice, often eaten with chilli sauce and cucumber. The variant shown in the image is khao khai chiao songkhrueang (Thai: ข้าวไข่เจียวทรงเครื่อง) where the omelet is topped with a minced pork and vegetable stir-fry.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวคลุกกะปิ
rice_dishes.description: Rice is fried with shrimp paste and served with sweet pork, sour mango, fried shrimp, chillies and shallots.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวหมกไก่
rice_dishes.description: The Thai version of a "chicken biryani". The name literally means "rice covered chicken". This Thai-Muslim dish is made by cooking rice together with the chicken curry.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวหมกเนื้อ
rice_dishes.description: The Thai version of a "beef biryani".

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวมันไก่
rice_dishes.description: Rice steamed with garlic served with sliced chicken, chicken broth and a spicy dipping sauce.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวหมูกรอบ
rice_dishes.description: Rice and crispy pork that is often, as here in this image, served with boiled egg and a bowl of broth. The sauce that always comes with khao mu krop is here served separately in the bowl at the top of the image.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวหมูกรอบหมูแดง
rice_dishes.description: Slices of mu krop (crispy pork) and mu daeng (red roast pork) served on rice, and often covered with a sticky soya and/or oyster-sauce based sauce. Very often, a clear soup, boiled egg, cucumber, and spring onion is served on the side. Sliced chillies in Chinese black vinegar and dark soy sauce are provided as a condiment for this dish.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวหน้าเป็ด
rice_dishes.description: Boiled rice with roast duck and duck broth on the side. It is served with sliced chillies in soy sauce as a condiment.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวเหนียว
rice_dishes.description: Khao niao is traditionally eaten using only the right hand. It is the staple food of Northern and Northeastern Thais.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวเนื้ออบ
rice_dishes.description: Rice with slices of baked beef, served with a spicy chilli dip.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวผัด
rice_dishes.description: Fried rice in Thailand can be made with different ingredients. Customarily served with fresh lime, cucumber, spring onions and nam pla phrik (chillies in fish sauce).

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวผัดอเมริกัน
rice_dishes.description: American fried rice is rice fried with onion, tomato, raisins and flavoured with ketchup. It is often garnished with some sausage, fried chicken and egg.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวผัดแกงเขียวหวาน
rice_dishes.description: Rice fried with green curry.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวผัดกะเพราหมู
rice_dishes.description: Rice fried with a certain variety of Thai basil called kaphrao (Ocimum tenuiflorum), sliced pork and chillies.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวผัดหนำเลี๊ยบ
rice_dishes.description: Rice fried with nam liap, the fruit of the Canarium album, also known as "Chinese olives".

rice_dishes.thai_name: Khao phat nam phrik long ruea
rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกลงเรือ
rice_dishes.description: Rice fried with Nam phrik long ruea (lit. "boat journey chilli paste") and pieces of khai khem (salted duck's eggs). Fried, sliced, sweet Chinese sausage called kun chiang (Thai: กุนเชียง) are also served here with some sliced cucumber on the side.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกนรก
rice_dishes.description: The name literally means "rice fried with chilli paste from hell". The rice is fried with nam phrik narok, a very spicy chilli paste made with fried catfish, grilled onion and garlic, grilled (dried) chillies, sugar, fish sauce and shrimp paste. Here it is served with mu yang (grilled pork) and nam chim chaeo, a spicy dipping sauce.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวต้ม
rice_dishes.description: Boiled rice in a light broth, usually with minced pork, chicken or fish. It is often eaten for breakfast.

rice_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวต้มกุ๊ย
rice_dishes.description: Plain rice is cooked to a porridge and eaten as the staple together with a variety of side dishes.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: บะหมี่แห้งเป็ด
noodle_dishes.description: Egg noodles served "dry" with slices of braised duck, and often, as shown on the image, together with "blood tofu". The broth is served on the side. It is originally a Chinese dish.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: บะหมี่หมูแดง
noodle_dishes.english_name: Egg noodle soup with red roast pork
noodle_dishes.description: Originally a Chinese dish, it is now common in Thailand. Often served with chillies in vinegar, and dried chilli flakes. The version shown in the photo also contains kiao kung (Thai: เกี๊ยวกุ้ง; prawn wontons).

noodle_dishes.thai_name: Khanom chin kaeng khiao wan kai
noodle_dishes.thai_script: ขนมจีนแกงเขียวหวานไก่
noodle_dishes.description: This noodle dish consists of green chicken curry served over khanom chin, fresh Thai rice noodles. It is usually accompanied by a selection of raw vegetables and herbs on the side. The chicken meat used in this particular version is chicken feet.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ขนมจีนน้ำเงี้ยว
noodle_dishes.description: A speciality of Northern Thailand, it is Thai fermented rice noodles served with pork or chicken blood tofu in a sauce made with pork broth and tomato, crushed fried dry chillies, pork blood, dry fermented soy bean, and dried red kapok flowers.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ขนมจีนน้ำยา
noodle_dishes.description: Thai rice noodles served with a fish based sauce called nam ya.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ขนมจีนซาวน้ำ
noodle_dishes.description: Cold rice noodles served as a salad with thick coconut milk, finely chopped pineapple, sliced raw garlic and Thai chillies, pounded dried prawns, shredded ginger, lime juice, fish sauce and sugar.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวซอย
noodle_dishes.description: Boiled as well as crispy fried egg noodles (bami) are served in a curry soup. The version with chicken is called khao soi kai, with beef it is called khao soi nuea.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวซอยแม่สาย
noodle_dishes.description: Khao soi Mae Sai is the name in Chiang Mai of a certain type of khao soi that is more common in Chiang Rai province, in the area along the border with Burma and Laos (Mae Sai is a border town in Chiang Rai province). It is a spicy soup-like dish, similar to the broth used in khanom chin nam ngiao, containing soft, wide rice noodles, pork ribs, congealed pork blood and minced pork. Tomatoes and fermented soy bean give it its specific taste. Sliced raw cabbage and bean sprouts are served on the side.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ข้าวซอยน้ำหน้า
noodle_dishes.description: Somewhat similar to khao soi Mae Sai, this variant from the eastern part of Chiang Rai Province is made with wide rice noodles in a clear pork broth. A spoonful of nam phrik ong (a sauce made from minced pork, tomato, fermented soy bean or shrimp paste, and dried chillies) is heaped on top of the noodles (nam na literally means "with sauce on top").

noodle_dishes.thai_script: กวยจั๊บ
noodle_dishes.description: Originally a Teochew Chinese dish (Chinese: 粿汁), it is a soup of pork broth with rolled up rice noodle sheets (resulting in rolls about the size of Italian penne), pork intestines, "blood tofu", and boiled egg.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำ
noodle_dishes.description: A soup of wide rice noodles, often with minced pork, pork balls or fish balls.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเนื้อเปื่อย
noodle_dishes.description: A beef noodle soup with slices of very tender beef (nuea pueay).

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวผัดขี้เมา
noodle_dishes.description: Spicy fried wide rice noodles.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวราดหน้า
noodle_dishes.description: Fried wide rice noodles with beef, pork, chicken or seafood in a thickened gravy.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเรือ
noodle_dishes.description: Rice noodles with beef or pork (and sometimes offal) in a brown broth which contains cinnamon, star anise and sometimes blood. It is spicy and sour.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: หมี่กรอบ
noodle_dishes.description: Deep fried rice vermicelli with a sweet and sour sauce.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ผัดมาม่า
noodle_dishes.description: Mama (Thai: มาม่า) is the most popular brand of instant noodles in Thailand and the brand name is commonly used, instead of the generic bami kueng samret rup (Thai: บะหมี่กึ่งสำเร็จรูป), to designate instant noodles. The particular version in the image has been stir-fried "drunken noodle"-style.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ผัดซีอิ๊ว
noodle_dishes.description: Usually wide rice noodles fried with chicken or pork, and soy sauce.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ผัดไทย
noodle_dishes.description: Stir fried medium size rice noodles (sen lek) with fish sauce, sugar, lime juice or tamarind pulp, ground peanuts, egg, bean sprouts, and Chinese chives (kuichai), combined with pork, chicken, seafood, or tofu.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ผัดวุ้นเส้น
noodle_dishes.description: Glass noodles are stir-fried with egg and vegetables, and a variety of ingredients such as meat, seafood, or with vegetarian alternatives.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: สปาเกตตีผัดขี้เมา
noodle_dishes.description: A Thai fusion dish where the name literally means spaghetti fried "shit-drunk" (khi mao = extremely drunk). An explanation is that any dish fried this way is easy to make, spicy, and uses whatever ingredients are available at that time; great after a night out drinking when still hungry.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: ต้มยำโบราณ
noodle_dishes.description: Tom yam boran is noodles served in a thick spicy sour sauce or broth, with crushed dried chillies, chopped peanuts and blanched vegetables such as bean sprouts. This version is bami mu tom yam boran: with egg noodles and pork.

noodle_dishes.thai_script: เย็นตาโฟ
noodle_dishes.description: The Thai version of the Chinese noodle dish Yong Tau Foo is slightly sweet, sour, salty and spicy.

miscellaneous.description: Literally translated khai dao means "star egg", referring to the star-like shape of the egg after it has been fried. Traditionally the egg is fried in large amounts of hot vegetable oil which produces a crispy outer texture. Khai dao mai suk is a fried egg where the yolk is still runny, the way it is most commonly eaten when served with, for instance, khao phat ("fried rice") or kaphrao mu rat khao ("pork fried with holy basil served with rice"). Fried egg with a (very) hard yolk, khai dao suk (mak), is needed when the fried egg is used for making yam khai dao: fried egg salad.
Oven-roasted pork, this Thai-Chinese dish is most often served sliced, with a sweet soy and five-spice powder sauce.

miscellaneous.thai_script: หมูรวมลวกจิ้ม
miscellaneous.description: This dish consist of several types of pork (intestines, liver, and other cuts) which have been shortly blanched in boiling water or stock and then served with fried garlic, spring onions and a spicy dipping sauce.

Fish prepared in 3 different ways: on the left of the image is pla sam rot (deep-fried served with a tangy sweet chilli sauce), in the middle pla nueng manao (steamed fish with a raw garlic, lime and chilli sauce), and on the right pla thot krathiam (deep-fried fish with deep-fried garlic).

Similar to roti canai/roti prata from Malaysia and Singapore, this Indian-style fried flatbread is eaten with certain curries. For a sweet version, see roti kluai khai below in the section "Sweet snacks and desserts". The word thitchu in the name of this dish, is a loanword from English meaning "tissue".

curries.description: It is a slowly stewed meat curry from northern Thailand. This particular version is made with beef.[4]

curries.thai_script: ฉู่ฉี่ ปลากะพง
curries.description: A semi-dry red curry with fried Snapper.

curries.thai_script: ฉู่ฉี่ปลาทูสด
curries.description: A semi-dry curry made with fresh (i.e. unsteamed and unsalted) pla thu (Rastrelliger brachysoma). The version in the image was made at a southern Thai restaurant.
A northern Thai curry with cha-om (the young leaves of the Acacia pennata) and dried fish.[5] This particular version also contained a mix of different types of mushroom.

curries.thai_script: แกงฟักใส่ไก่
curries.description: A northern Thai curry made with winter melon and chicken. It is also known under the name kaeng fak khio.[6]

curries.thai_script: แกงดอกสะแล
curries.description: A northern Thai curry that is made from the unopened flower buds of the shrub Broussonetia kurzii (J. D. Hooker) Corner. These flower buds are only available in northern Thailand from mid-February until late March.
A Burmese influenced curry of stewed meat (usually pork), peanuts, dried chillies and tamarind juice but without coconut milk. Thin strips of fresh ginger are added in before serving.
A northern Thai curry made with pork and a variety of mushrooms.

A Northern Thai dish where one or more types of curry are refried with glass noodles and other ingredients such as kaffir lime leaves, lemongrass and bamboo shoots. At least one of the curries used in this recipe should be the Northern Thai pork curry called kaeng hangle.
It is a Thai-Muslim dish which is mostly known in the West as "Thai yellow curry". It is of Indian origin and is often made with chicken and potatoes. It can also be made with other meats or seafood.
A spicy curry of herbs, vegetables, cha-om leaves (a kind of acacia tree), and meat (chicken, water buffalo, pork or frog). It does not contain any coconut milk.
A northern Thai curry made with boiled whole jackfruit, pork, tomatoes and chopped chakhan (Piper interruptum; "pepper vine").[7]

curries.thai_script: แกงเขียวหวาน
curries.description: A coconut curry made with fresh green chillies and flavoured with Thai basil, usually with chicken (kaeng khiao wan kai) or fish balls (kaeng khiao wan luk chin pla).

curries.thai_script: แกงขี้เหล็ก
curries.description: This creamy curry has as its main ingredient the leaves and flower buds of the Senna siamea tree (khilek in Thai).

A type of Thai curry which uses a larger amount of turmeric in the paste than is usually the norm. A popular preparation is with prawns and pineapple. This particular version is called kaeng khua het fang (Thai: แกงคั่วเห็ดฟาง): with straw mushrooms.

curries.thai_script: แกงคั่วหมูใบชะมวง
curries.description: A thick central Thai curry with pork and the leaves of chamuang or Garcinia cowa, a tree related to the mangosteen.

curries.thai_script: แกงกระด้าง
curries.description: A pork curry aspic (jelly) from northern Thailand which is eaten cold.

A sour spicy curry that does not contain coconut milk and is yellow in colour due to the use of turmeric, often with fish and vegetables, such as bamboo shoots as in the version in the photo. In southern Thailand it is called kaeng som but due to it being different from the central Thai kaeng som, it is called kaeng lueang ("yellow curry") elsewhere. It should not be confused with what is known as "yellow curry" outside of Thailand.

curries.thai_script: แกงมัสมั่น
curries.description: A thick, Indian style curry containing coconut milk, usually of stewed beef or, as in the image, chicken. This curry contains roasted dried spices that are rarely found in other Thai curries.
A spicy Lanna "curry" with meat and several kinds of vegetables, and without any coconut milk. The version shown in the photo is with chicken.
Traditionally made with wild boar, most often pork or chicken is used nowadays. This curry, as most curries from northern Thailand, does not contain coconut milk.

curries.thai_script: แกงผักบุ้งใส่ปลา
curries.description: A northern Thai curry made with "morning glory" and fish. This particular version uses catfish.

curries.thai_name: Kaeng phak kat cho kraduk mu
curries.thai_script: แกงผักกาดจอกระดูกหมู
curries.description: A somewhat spicy soup/curry (kaeng) made with cabbage (phak kat cho, a variety of Brassica rapa chinensis) and pork ribs (kraduk mu). As is usual with Northern Thai "curries", it does not contain any coconut milk.

curries.thai_script: แกงผักเลือด
curries.description: A northern Thai curry made with the leaves of the Ficus virens. This version is with pork.

curries.thai_script: แกงผักเซียงดา
curries.description: A northern Thai curry made with the leaves of the vine Gymnema inodorum and dried fish. In this particular version, snakehead fish is used.[8]

curries.thai_script: แกงผักหวานป่า
curries.description: A Northern Thai curry made with the leaves of the woody plant Melientha suavis Pierre, glass noodles and dried fish.[9]
A so-called dry, Indian influenced coconut curry with beef (phanaeng nuea, Thai: พะแนงเนื้อ), chicken, pork or seafood such as soft shell crab.

A spicy red curry made with dried chillies, containing coconut milk. It can be made with different meats, seafood or tofu, in combination with (several types of) eggplant(s) and sometimes other vegetables. Fresh green peppercorns and Thai basil are often added to enhance the flavour.

curries.thai_script: แกงเผ็ดเป็ดย่าง
curries.description: Red curry with roast duck is the quintessential mix of the Thai (red curry) and Chinese (red roast duck) cuisines. This dish often also contains grapes and/or pineapple.
A northern Thai curry made with chopped banana flower and pork.

A hot and sour Thai curry/soup made with tamarind paste and fish (often pla chon ["Snakehead fish"]). Kaeng som cha-om thot (Thai: แกงส้มชะอมทอด) is a version of the dish which features deep-fried cha-om (Acacia leaves) as one of its ingredients.
A thick, spicy vegetable curry made with turmeric, a sauce made from fish innards (tai pla), and shrimp paste, containing roasted fish, bamboo shoots and eggplant.

One of the dishes mentioned in King Rama II's poem on Thai dishes, it is a central Thai curry originally made with the fatty belly part of the Pangasius Larnaudii (thae pho; shark catfish) but now more often belly pork is used as is the case with the version shown in the photo. The other main ingredient in this curry is phak bung Chin (Chinese water spinach).
A northern Thai curry made with the stalks of the Colocasia gigantea and (cat)fish. Colocasia gigantea is called tun (Thai: ตูน) in the northern Thai language and khun (Thai: คูน) in standard Thai.

curries.thai_name: Kaeng yot maphrao on sai kai
curries.thai_script: แกงยอดมะพร้าวอ่อนใส่ไก่
curries.description: A northern Thai curry made with "coconut heart" and chicken.[10] The taste of "coconut heart" is similar to bamboo shoots but much sweeter.
A northern Thai curry made with the tender core of the trunk of the banana plant.[11]
A very spicy, dry fried curry made with chopped meat (usually beef, chicken, pork or lamb) served with a large amount of shredded fresh kaffir lime leaves.

curries.thai_script: คั่วกระดูกหมู
curries.description: A very spicy and, for Thai standards, "dry" curry with pork ribs. It is a Southern Thai speciality.
A curry dish from Northern Thailand containing chicken. The version in the image also contains sliced banana flower.[12]

soups.thai_script: ไก่ตุ๋นยาจีน
soups.description: The name literally translates to "chicken stewed with Chinese medicine". It contains medicinal herbs, one of them the dried fruit of the wolfberry, a.k.a. goji berries (Thai: เก๋ากี้; kaoki). The dish is of Chinese origin.

This is a clear broth, usually served together with khao man kai (chicken rice), khao mok (Thai biryani), khao kha mu (pork trotter simmered in soy sauce served with rice), khao na pet (red roast duck on rice), or khao mu daeng (red roast pork on rice). The broth can be made from chicken and/or pork, or it can be wholly vegetarian. The version served with duck is usually made from duck bones. It will often contain sliced hua chai thao (daikon; also known as phak kat hua in Thai) and hua chai po khem (a Chinese ingredient of dried and salted chopped turnip). Garlic, ginger, and pepper are often used as additional ingredients. It is most often garnished with fresh coriander leaves and/or spring onion.

soups.thai_script:
ต้มจืด
แกงจืด
soups.description: A light vegetable, chicken or pork broth with vegetables and celery, to which minced pork, soft tofu, seaweed, glass noodles and mushroom can be added. This soup can also be called Kaeng chuet (Thai: แกงจืดวุ้นเส้น).
A mild to spicy soup with coconut milk, galangal (kha) and chicken. Mushrooms can be added to the chicken or substitute it.

It is a spicy and sour soup somewhat similar to Tom yam. The sourness however does not derive from lime juice but through the use of tamarind juice. The version in the image contains fried smoked fish, tomato and mushrooms.

A clear soup made with bitter melon (also known as bitter gourd; Momordica charantia) of Chinese origin. It is often stuffed with minced pork or with minced pork mixed with glass noodles as on this image. The full name of the latter version would then be tom mara yat sai mu sap wunsen.

soups.thai_script: ต้มผักกาดดองหมู
soups.description: A soup of boiled pickled Chinese cabbage and pork ribs. This dish is Chinese in origin.
A spicy soup made with stewed meat (usually pork, chicken or beef), roasted fresh herbs and spices, ground roasted rice, and generous amounts of lime juice and fresh herbs just before serving.

soups.thai_script: ต้มส้มกระดูกหมู
soups.description: Tom som translates to "sour soup". This particular version is a basic one with only pork ribs (kraduk mu) and it derives its sourness from lime juice. Other types of tom som can also use tamarind for acidity, or a combination of both lime and tamarind, and can be made from a multitude of ingredients: meats as well as seafood, and vegetables.
A hot and sour broth made from lemon grass, galangal, kaffir lime leaves, dried chillies and lime juice, usually with prawns (Tom yam kung) or chicken (Tom yam kai).

soups.thai_script: ต้มเยื่อไผ่
soups.description: It is a clear broth with, amongst other ingredients, yuea phai ("bamboo fungus"; Phallus indusiatus)

salads.description: Minced or finely chopped raw fish in spicy salad dressing. It is a popular raw fish dish in Isan and a common source of infection with Opisthorchis viverrini (Southeast Asian liver fluke).
Northeastern style lap is a spicy and sour salad of minced raw or cooked meat (mainly pork, chicken or duck), shallots or onions, lime juice, fish sauce, chillies, ground roasted rice and mint.

Northern Thai lap is completely different from lap from northeastern Thailand. Northern Thai lap is made by mixing raw or cooked minced meat (mainly pork, beef, chicken or fish) with an elaborate mix of dry spices and herbs. The northern Thai lap does not contain lime juice or fish sauce. The version in the image is lap khua, meaning that the meat has been fried.

salads.thai_script: ลาบเนื้อดิบ
salads.description: A northern Thai lap-style salad of sliced raw beef (the version in the image also shows slices of raw beef tripe) and ground, dried spices.
A very spicy salad made with pork (mu) and somewhat identical to lap, except that the meat is cut into thin strips rather than minced.

Naem sausage (pork fermented with sticky rice)[13] is mixed with boiled rice and then deep-fried. The salad is made by crumbling the deep-fried balls and mixing in sliced shallots, dried chillies, fish sauce and lime juice. It is served with raw vegetables and herbs.

salads.thai_script: เนื้อย่างน้ำตก
salads.description: With a similar "dressing" as larb, this dish is made with sliced grilled beef. "Nam tok" means "waterfall" in Thai and it is thought that the meat juices should run out from the meat like a waterfall.

A spicy salad of prawns, sliced lemongrass, culantro and/or other herbs, and shallots, with a dressing of lime juice, sweet chilli paste (Nam phrik phao - optional), fish sauce, pounded garlic and bird's eye chili. The version shown in the image also contained minced pork.

A spicy salad of sliced grilled pork, sliced lemongrass, mint, culantro (optional) and shallots, with a dressing of lime juice, sweet chilli paste (Nam phrik phao - optional), fish sauce, pounded garlic and bird's eye chili.

salads.thai_script: พล่าเนื้อมะเขืออ่อน
salads.description: A Thai salad made with medium rare beef and Thai aubergines. The sliced, raw eggplants are mixed in with the warm beef to soften them (makhuea on means "soft aubergine"). This particular version of the salad was served with a nam tok-style dressing.

salads.thai_script: ส้าเนื้อสะดุ้ง
salads.description: A northern Thai speciality, made with medium rare, thinly sliced beef. Other ingredients for this dish are the elaborate phrik lap Lanna spices-and-chilli mix, onions, some broth, and fresh herbs such as kraphao (holy basil) or phak phai (Vietnamese coriander) although this particular version was made using saranae (spearmint). This particular version also contained nam phia, the partially digested contents from the first of the four stomachs of cattle, for added flavour.[14]

salads.thai_script: ส้มตำไข่เค็ม
salads.description: A variation of the standard papaya som tam with salted eggs.

salads.thai_script: ส้มตำปลาร้า
salads.description: Regarded as the original som tam, this version of green papaya salad contains pla ra (a sauce of fermented fish), and very often also brined rice paddy crabs, and makok (the fruit of the Spondias mombin) besides the usual ingredients for som tam. It does not however contain peanuts. It is also known as som tam Lao or, for short, as just tam Lao after the Lao people of Laos and of the Isan region of Thailand.
Green papaya salad with brined rice paddy crabs.
Som tam Thai with peanuts, dried shrimp and palm sugar, is the central Thai variant of green papaya salad.

A spicy Northern Thai salad made with boiled green whole jackfruit which has been mashed with a mortar and pestle, and minced pork. It is normally eaten with sticky rice and (as seen on the image) with khaep mu (pork cracklings).

Chopped and then pounded grilled long green eggplant (makhuea yao; Thai: มะเขือยาว), grilled green chillies, raw garlic and salt put in a banana leaf package mixed together with hard-boiled egg. It's a speciality of Northern Thailand where it is traditionally eaten with sticky rice.
A som tam style salad with tangy unripe mango "au Julienne" as its main ingredient. The version in the image contains pla haeng thot, deep-fried sun-dried anchovies.

salads.thai_name: Tam maphrao on sen mi krop
salads.thai_script: ตำมะพร้าวอ่อนเส้นหมี่กรอบ
salads.description: A som tam style salad made with the meat of a young coconut and served with crispy deep-fried thin Chinese rice noodles.
A spicy Thai salad made with mu yo, a Thai pork sausage which is often also described in Thailand as "Vietnamese sausage". The dressing is somewhat similar to that of som tam.

salads.thai_script: ตำผลไม้รวม
salads.description: The fruits used in this particular salad show the fusion aspect of Thai cuisine, as it incorporates "modern" (for Thais) fruit such as apples and grapes besides traditional fruit such as pineapple and guava. The dressing is made with pounded garlic, sugar, chillies, dried shrimp, lime juice and fish sauce, and is similar to that of som tam.

salads.thai_script: ตำส้มโอน้ำปู
salads.description: It is a spicy pomelo salad which uses crab extract as a flavouring. This black sauce is achieved by pounding pu na ("ricefield crabs", Somanniathelphusa) to a pulp, straining the juices which are then boiled and reduced until the sauce becomes as thick as molasses.

A general name for many types of sour Thai salads. The main ingredient can be vegetable, fruit, meat, seafood and even noodles, which can be raw, cooked, grilled, fried or deep-fried. The basic recipe for the dressing consists of sliced shallots or onion, fish sauce, lime juice, sugar, bird's eye chillies, tomato and Chinese celery (khuen chai).
A spicy Thai salad made with young, fresh tea leaves.
Made with thinly sliced, boiled pig's ears, the version in the image also contained fresh mint, lime juice, shallots, lemon grass, fish sauce and sugar.

salads.thai_script: ยำหัวปลีทอด
salads.description: A spicy Thai "yam"-style salad with deep-fried slices of banana blossom as its main ingredient.
A spicy Thai salad made with blood cockles.
A spicy Thai salad made with fried egg (khai dao).

salads.thai_script: ยำขมิ้นขาวกุ้ง
salads.description: A spicy Thai salad made with finely sliced (au Julienne) "white curcuma" (probably Curcuma zedoaria), shredded coconut, cooked prawns, sliced shallots, dried chillies, fresh green bird's eye chillies, roasted cashew nuts, and crispy fried onion rings.

salads.thai_script: ยำกุนเชียง
salads.description: A Thai salad made with a sweet dried pork sausage called kun chiang. This sausage is of Chinese origin. This dish is often eaten with plain rice congee (khao tom kui; Thai: ข้าวต้มกุ๊ย).
A Thai salad made with crispy belly pork (mu krop).
A spicy yam-style Thai salad with mu yo (Vietnamese sausage).

salads.thai_name: Yam mu yo thot khai dao
salads.thai_script: ยำหมูยอทอดไข่ดาว
salads.description: A spicy Thai salad made with crispy fried mu yo (Vietnamese sausage) and khai dao (fried egg).
A Thai salad containing sausage made from fermented raw pork and sticky rice (naem sausage).
A Northern Thai salad made with strips of boiled bamboo shoots, shallots, herbs, fish sauce, lime juice, and chillies.

salads.thai_name: Yam no mai sai nam pu
salads.thai_script: ยำหน่อไม้ใส่น้ำปู
salads.description: A northern Thai salad made with boiled bamboo shoots and a thick paste made from the rice paddy crabs.

salads.thai_script: ยำเนื้อย่าง
salads.description: A spicy salad of grilled beef, shallots and Thai celery or spearmint.
A salad of edible fern shoots (Diplazium esculentum) and pork.

salads.thai_script: ยำปลาดุกฟู
salads.description: Crispy fried shredded pla duk (catfish) served with a spicy and tangy green mango salad.
A Thai salad (yam) made with fried sun-dried salted fish (pla khem).
Made with short mackerel (pla thu).

A northern Thai "salad" of roughly chopped, blanched vegetables that are then refried with a chilli paste. It is served here together with northern Thai pork cracklings and deep-fried, sun-dried chillies.[15]
A salad made with pomelo. The other ingredients are: sliced red bird's eye chillies, deep-fried sun-dried anchovies, roasted peanuts, fish sauce and tamarind juice.

salads.thai_script: ยำตะไคร้กุ้งสด
salads.description: A spicy "yam-style" salad with finely sliced raw lemongrass and prawns.
A spicy salad with mixed seafood (cuttlefish, shelled prawns, mussels), shallots, lime juice, fish sauce and Thai celery.
A Thai salad with winged beans, salted eggs, toasted coconut, shallots, fish sauce, lime juice and chillies. The version in this image also contains squid.

salads.thai_script: ยำวุ้นเส้น
salads.description: A spicy salad with glass noodles (cellophane noodles), minced chicken or pork and often either mixed seafood, squid or prawns. Cloud ear fungus also often features in this dish.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ไก่ผัดขิง
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: A simple dish of fried slices of chicken with sliced ginger, soy sauce, fish sauce and chillies.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ไก่ผัดเม็ดมะม่วงหิมพานต์
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: The Thai Chinese version of the Sichuan style fried chicken with cashew nuts known as Kung Pao chicken, stir-fried with whole dried chillies.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ไข่ยัดไส้
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: An omelette is fried filled with various ingredients of choice (minced beef or pork, prawns, and vegetables) and then folded over.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: คั่วจิ๊นส้มใส่ไข่
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Northern Thai pickled pork stir-fried with egg.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: คั่วห่อ
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Glass noodles are stir-fried with left-overs from other dishes. Unlike kaeng ho, this dish will not contain any left-over curry dishes. It was traditionally eaten at the end of a ceremony or festival. It is served here with pork rinds.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: คั่วหน่อไม้ใส่หมู
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Stir-fried bamboo shoots with pork. In this particular version, the pork is minced.[16]

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: กะเพราหอยลาย
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Undulated surf clam stir-fried with holy basil (Ocimum tenuiflorum)

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ไข่ลูกเขย
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Boiled eggs are (deep-)fried until crispy on the outside, and then served sliced with a tangy sauce made from tamarind juice. The Thai name literally translates as "son-in-law eggs".

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: กุ้งทอดกระเทียมพริกไทย
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.english_name: Deep fried prawns with garlic and pepper
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Prawns fried with garlic and fresh peppercorns.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: หมูผัดพริกขิง
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Sliced pork fried with yardlong beans and kaffir lime leaves in a sweet chilli paste. Sometimes red curry paste is used instead of the phrik khing chilli paste.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: หมูผัดสะตอ
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Sliced pork stir-fried with sato (the beans of the Parkia speciosa, also known as "stink bean" or "bitter bean"), onion, garlic, fish sauce, chillies and oyster sauce.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: หมูผัดสะตอภาคใต้
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: A spicy, southern Thai, version of mu phat sato where the pork and "stink beans" are fried with a copious amount of chillies and chilli paste.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: หมูหวาน
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Sliced pork is simmered or fried with sugar and soy sauce until the sauce is reduced and coats the meat.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: หน่อไม้ฝรั่งผัดกุ้ง
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Green asparagus stir-fried with prawns, garlic, sliced chillies, fish sauce and oyster sauce.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: เนื้อผัดใบยี่หร่า
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Besides beef and basil, other ingredients are garlic, chillies, light soya sauce and fish sauce. African basil leaves have a slight anise taste.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผักบุ้งไฟแดง
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Morning-glory (a.k.a. water spinach) stir fried with yellow bean sauce, garlic and chillies. It is a very popular vegetable dish in Thailand.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผักคะน้าน้ำมันหอย
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.english_name: Chinese kale stir-fried with oyster sauce
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Originally a Chinese dish, it has been adapted to Thai taste by adding fish sauce to the recipe, and by omitting the ginger. Here with fried shiitake mushroom.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดบวบ
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Stir-fried luffa (sponge gourd) with pork/shrimp and egg or just egg.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดดอกหอม
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Stir-fried onion flowers with pork and pork liver.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดคะน้าหมูกรอบ
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Khana (gailan or Chinese kale) is stir fried with crispy pork (mu krop), garlic, oyster sauce, soy sauce, pepper and (optionally) sliced chillies.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดแขนงหมู
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Stir-fried khanaeng with pork, garlic, oyster sauce, fish sauce and white pepper. Khanaeng are the sprouts of Chinese broccoli and grow from the root after the main stem has been harvested. The taste is in between Brussels sprouts and kale, and very sweet.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดกะเพรา
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Minced beef, pork, chicken or whole prawns stir fried with Thai holy basil, chillies, garlic and soya sauce.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดแหนมไส่ไข่
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Naem sausage (made from fermented raw pork skin and sticky rice) stir fried with egg.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดหน่อไม้ใส่ไข่
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Stir-fried bamboo shoots and egg.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดผักโขม
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Thai spinach (Amaranthus spinosus; Thai name: Phak khom nam; Thai script: ผักโขมหนาม) is often stir-fried with minced pork and egg.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดผักรวม
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Stir fried combination of vegetables depending on availability and preference. Usually fried with oyster sauce.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดพริก
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Stir fried meat (usually beef) or seafood with chillies, garlic and ginger.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ผัดยอดฟักแม้ว
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Yot sayongte, which is also known in Thailand as yot fak meao (yot meaning "shoots"), are the young vines and leaves of a certain type of melon (chayote, originally from Central America) which in Thailand grows mainly in the mountains up north. These greens have a very sweet taste and combine extremely well with oyster sauce.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ปูนิ่มผัดผงกะหรี่
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Deep-fried pieces of soft-shell crab which have been stir-fried with egg and curry powder.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ปลาดุกผัดเผ็ด
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Slices of catfish (most often pre-fried) are stir-fried in a sauce made with red curry paste. Pea eggplant feature in this dish for added taste and texture.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ปลากะพงผัดขึ้นฉ่าย
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Barramundi (often called "sea bass" in Thailand) stir-fried with Chinese celery, light soy sauce, garlic, ginger and fermented soy beans.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ปลาหมึกผัดพริกเผา
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Squid stir-fried with sweet and mild chilli paste (nam phrik phao), onion, garlic, spring onion and sliced large red chillies. Paprika can be used instead of chillies if a milder version is preferred.

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ตับไก่ผัดพริกสด
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: Chicken liver fried with young (mainly green) chillies, light soy sauce, oyster sauce, onion, spring onion, black pepper, and garlic. Here it is served with rice and a fried egg (khai dao).

fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.thai_script: ถั่วงอกปลาเค็ม
fried_and_stir-fried_dishes.description: A stir-fried dish of mung bean sprouts, salted fish, chillies and garlic.

deep-fried_dishes.thai_script: ไก่ห่อใบเตย
deep-fried_dishes.description: Pieces of marinated chicken are wrapped in fragrant pandan leaves and then deep fried.

deep-fried_dishes.thai_script: ไก่ทอดตะไคร้
deep-fried_dishes.description: Pieces of chicken are deep fried together with finely chopped or shredded lemongrass, and served with a sweet chilli sauce.

The version of kai thot as shown in the image is made in the Southern Thai manner, having been marinated with khamin (turmeric) and served with krueng thae (crispy fried chopped garlic and turmeric) as a topping.
Deep fried pork skin. Khaep mu eaten with nam phrik num (grilled green chilli dip) from Chiang Mai is renowned in the whole of Thailand.
Cooked belly pork is first marinated and then deep fried until crispy. Often used sliced in vegetables stir fries.

deep-fried_dishes.thai_script: หมูทอดกระเทียม
หนังไก่ทอด
deep-fried_dishes.description: Crispy, deep-fried chicken skin. It can be eaten as a snack or together with chilli pastes or salads.

deep-fried_dishes.thai_script: หน่อยัดไส้ทอด
deep-fried_dishes.description: A northern Thai speciality of deep-fried bamboo shoots with a filling of minced pork.

deep-fried_dishes.thai_script: ปีกไก่สอดไส้ทอด
deep-fried_dishes.description: Deep fried, partially de-boned chicken wings, stuffed usually with minced pork.

Cuts of Giant snakehead fish (pla chado) are first salted and sun-dried for three days, and then deep-fried. This dish is somewhat similar to pla chado daet diao from central Thailand but there the fish is only dried for only one day, making the taste less intense.

deep-fried_dishes.thai_script: ปลากรายทอดกระเทียม
deep-fried_dishes.description: Deep-fried pla krai ("Clown Knifefish") and garlic. It is served with a spicy dipping sauce on the side made from coriander root, lime juice, fresh bird's eye chillies, garlic, sugar and fish sauce.

deep-fried_dishes.thai_script: ปลานิลทอดสมุนไพร
deep-fried_dishes.description: Deep-fried pla nin ("Nile Tilipia") served with deep-fried herbs such as lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, garlic, and fingerroot (Boesenbergia rotunda). A chilli-lime dip is served on the side as a condiment.
Deep fried fish with a sweet, tangy and spicy tamarind sauce.
A simple deep-fried fish, most often served with a spicy dipping sauce. The fish in this image is pla nin, a Nile Tilapia.

deep-fried_dishes.thai_script: ปลาทอดขมิ้น
deep-fried_dishes.description: Typical for southern Thai cuisine, this deep-fried fish has first been marinated in a spice mixture which includes a large amount of turmeric (khamin). In addition, this particular version was topped with crispy deep-fried chopped garlic and turmeric. It is often served with raw vegetables on the side, and a spicy dipping sauce.

Deep-fried pla wong (literally meaning "circle fish"): fish which have first been cut open, arranged into a circle and then sun-dried. Here it is served Southern Thai style with a spoonful of a deep-fried mix of minced garlic, galangal, and turmeric.

A mixture of cooked crab meat, pork, garlic and pepper, deep fried inside the crab shells and usually served with nam chim buoy (Thai: น้ำจิ้มบ๋วย, plum sauce). Instead of being fried in the crab shell it is also sometimes served as patties.

deep-fried_dishes.thai_script: ซี่โครงหมูทอด
deep-fried_dishes.description: Deep-fried pork ribs. The version in the image however, had first been boiled, then marinated, then deep-fried with garlic, and then again stir-fried with a sweet and tangy tamarind sauce just before serving.

grilled_dishes.description: A Northern Thai "soufflé" of egg, minced pork, herbs and curry paste that is slowly grilled inside a banana leaf wrapper over a charcoal fire.[17]

grilled_dishes.thai_script: แอ็บอ่องออ
grilled_dishes.description: Roughly chopped pig's brain mixed with egg and curry paste are grilled over a low fire, wrapped inside banana leaves [18]

grilled_dishes.thai_script: แอ็บปลาน้อย
grilled_dishes.description: Freshwater small fry and brine shrimp are mixed with curry paste and then grilled over a low fire wrapped inside banana leaves

grilled_dishes.thai_script: จิ๊นส้มหมก
grilled_dishes.description: Chin som is the northern Thai version of the pickled pork sausage called naem. In chin som mok (lit. "covered chin som") the pickled pork is grilled inside a banana leaf before serving.
Grilled marinated chicken, usually eaten together with Som tam (papaya salad).

grilled_dishes.thai_script: คอหมูย่างกระทะร้อน
grilled_dishes.description: Kho mu yang kratha ron literally translates to "pork neck grilled on a hot skillet".

grilled_dishes.thai_script: กุ้งย่าง/กุ้งเผา
grilled_dishes.description: Grilled prawns are normally served with a nam chim, a spicy dipping sauce, made with mashed raw garlic and green bird's eye chillies, sugar, fish sauce and lime juice.

Sliced grilled pork with a dressing (nam chim) of mashed garlic, green bird's eye chillies, sugar, fish sauce and lime juice. Here it is served with additional sliced bird's eye chillies and raw garlic on a bed of ice-water chilled sliced raw phak khana (Chinese broccoli)

Originally from the Isan region of Thailand, the fatty parts of belly pork, together with the skin, are preferred over lean meat. It is served with nam chim chaeo, a spicy dipping sauce made with dried chillies and roasted, then pounded, sticky rice.

Grilled banana leaf cups containing a mixture of ant eggs, chicken eggs and some salt. After grilling the dish is sprinkled with chopped spring onion and pepper. The ant eggs make the dish much more creamy. It can also be eaten as a snack.

grilled_dishes.thai_script: ไส้กรอกอีสาน
grilled_dishes.description: Grilled, fermented pork and sticky rice sausage, originally from the Isan region of Thailand. It can be shaped like a sausage as in the image, or as round balls.[20] It is also often eaten as a snack at festivals and fairs, and served together with sliced ginger, bird's eye chillies and raw cabbage.

grilled_dishes.thai_script: ไส้หมูปิ้ง

grilled_dishes.description: A grilled sausage of ground pork mixed with spices and herbs,[21] and which is often served with chopped fresh ginger and chillies at a meal.

grilled_dishes.thai_script: เสือร้องไห้
grilled_dishes.description: Suea rong hai literally means "weeping tiger". It is grilled marinated beef which is eaten with vegetables and Nam chim chaeo dipping sauce.

steamed_or_blanched_dishes.description: Eaten blanched as a dish with khao tom kui (plain rice congee), the taste is similar to that of spinach or samphire
A Thai curry "pâté" or "soufflé" of fish, spices, coconut milk and egg, steamed in a banana leaf cup and topped with thick coconut cream before serving.

steamed_or_blanched_dishes.thai_script: ห่อหมกมะพร้าวอ่อน
steamed_or_blanched_dishes.description: A Thai curry "pâté" or "soufflé" of mixed seafood and the soft meat of a young coconut, here served inside a coconut.

steamed_or_blanched_dishes.thai_script: ปลานึ่งมะนาว
steamed_or_blanched_dishes.description: Steamed fish which is drenched in a spicy garlic, chilli, chicken stock and lime juice dressing.[22]

stewed_dishes.description: Egg stewed with meat in soy sauce, garlic, ginger and phong phalo (Thai: ผงพะโล้; five-spice powder). Meats used in khai phalo tend to be pork (belly or trotter) or chicken wings. Other ingredients, such as mushrooms and fried tofu, can also be incorporated. The dish is of Chinese origin.[23] Similar dishes are mu phalo and kha mu phalo (using only pork, and ham hocks), kai phalo (chicken) and pet phalo (duck).

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำจิ้มแจ่ว
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: It is a sticky, sweet and spicy dipping sauce made with dried chillies, fish sauce, palm sugar, lime juice and coarsely ground roasted sticky rice. Often served as a dip with mu yang (grilled pork).

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำจิ้มไก่
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A very common all-round chilli dipping sauce with the consistency of a thick syrup, it is medium spicy and very sweet. Often used as a dipping sauce for grilled chicken (kai means "chicken"), it can also be used as a generic chilli sauce for other dishes. It forms the base of a few other types of nam chim, such as nam chim thot man pla ("dipping sauce for deep-fried fish cakes").

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำจิ้มแป๊ะซะ
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A spicy dipping sauce eaten with steamed fish wrapped in raw lettuce or cabbage.

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำจิ้มสะเต๊ะ
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A peanut sauce which is normally served with satay.

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำปลาพริก
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: Colloquially called phrik nam pla, it is a standard sauce served with every Thai buffet style meal, fried rice or fried noodles, and used as a kind of "salt". It is made by mixing fish sauce with some lime juice, chopped bird's eye chillies and often also sliced garlic.

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำพริกอีเก๋
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A northern Thai chilli paste made with chillies, sliced aubergine, pork rinds, and fermented shrimp paste.[24]

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำพริกกะปิ
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A pungent chilli dip made with shrimp paste, pounded dried shrimp, bird's eye chillies, garlic, lime juice, fish sauce, (palm) sugar and, optionally, pea sized aubergines; most often eaten as part of the dish called Nam phrik pla thu.

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำพริกข่า
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A Northern Thai fried chilli paste containing galangal (kha). It is often eaten, as seen here, with steamed het nang fa (Thai script: เห็ดนางฟ้า; lit. "fairy mushroom"; Pleurotus pulmonarius).

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำพริกแคบหมู
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A northern Thai chilli paste of mashed grilled green chillies, deep-fried pork rinds, fresh garlic and salt.[25]

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำพริกลงเรือ
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: The name means "chilli paste for in a boat" as it was often eaten while travelling the rivers of Thailand by boat. A sweet, savoury and spicy chilli dip, it is served together with fresh vegetables, salted egg and sweet pork. This version also included khamin khao ("white curcuma") and the slightly sour and bitter leaves of makok (Spondias mombin)

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำพริกหนุ่ม
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A paste of pounded roasted large green chillies, roasted shallots, roasted garlic, coriander leaves, lime juice and fish sauce; eaten with steamed and raw vegetables, khaep mu (crispy pork rind) and sticky rice.

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำพริกอ่อง
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: Resembling a thick Bolognese sauce, it is made with dried chillies, minced pork and tomato; eaten with steamed and raw vegetables, and sticky rice.

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำพริกเผา
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A sweet roasted chilli paste, often used as an ingredient in Tom yam or when frying meat or seafood, and also popular as a spicy "jam" on bread or toast.

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: น้ำพริกปลาจี่
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A chilli paste made with grilled fish, roasted chillies, roasted shallots and roasted garlic, lemongrass and shrimp paste. It's normally served with both steamed and raw vegetables and/or other leaves.[26]

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: ปูอ่อง or อ่องปู
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: A northern Thai speciality that is eaten as a pungent dipping sauce for sticky rice. It is made by collecting the "fat" of rice field crabs (Parathelphusidae) and grilling this inside the crab shell.[27]

dipping_sauces_and_pastes.thai_script: ซอสศรีราชา
dipping_sauces_and_pastes.description: It is a hot sauce made from sun-ripened chilli peppers, vinegar, garlic, sugar and salt. It is commonly known in Thailand as sot Siracha (sot is the Thai pronunciation of the English word "sauce"), but also as nam chim Siracha or nam phrik Siracha. The name is derived from the seaside town of Si Racha.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: จิ้งหรีดทอด
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Deep-fried crickets, either Gryllus bimaculatus or, as shown in the image, Acheta domesticus. This dish is often eaten as a snack to go with drinks.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ไก่รมควัน
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Smoked chicken is often eaten as a snack to go with drinks.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: กะหรี่ปั๊บ
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Deep-fried pastry shells usually containing a chicken meat and potato curry.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: แคบหมู
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Deep fried crispy pork rinds, often eaten with nam phrik num and other northern Thai dips

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ขนมจีบ
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: The Thai version of the Chinese steamed dumplings called siu mai in Cantonese. The colour indicates the filling: the green dumplings contain a mix of minced pork and crab meat, the others have a filling of only minced pork.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ขนมกุยช่าย
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Originally a dish of the Teochew people called "gu chai gue" (Chinese script: 韭菜馃) in the Teochew language, these are steamed dumplings made from rice powder and a filling of garlic chives. The dipping sauce for this dish is soy sauce which often is spiced with dried chilli flakes. This particular version was fried to give it a crispy texture.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ขนมโตเกียว
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Literally translated it means "Tokyo cake", it is a Thai style crêpe wrapped around a hot dog and sweet chilli sauce. The chilli sauce can also be served on the side as a dip. Other versions of khanom Tokiao use yam or sweet condensed milk as a filling.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ข้าวพันงาม้วน
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Rolled khao phan with sesame seeds. Khao phan is a speciality from northern Laos which in Thailand is only found in Uttaradit province. Rice flour is mixed with water and let to ferment overnight. The resulting batter is then spread out thinly over a cloth stretched out over a steamer, covered with a hood and let to steam for a few minutes. Rolled up it is served with a chilli dip.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ข้าวพันผัก
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Khao phan are thin, steamed rice sheets made from the fermented batter of rice flour mixed with water. Here served as a wrap for stir-fried vegetables.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ลูกชิ้นปิ้ง
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Meatballs made from fish, pork, beef or chicken are grilled on a stick and served with a spicy and tangy dipping sauce. The ones shown on the image are made with pork and beef. It is commonly sold from street stalls in Thailand.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: มะม่วงน้ำปลาหวาน
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Tart, unripe mango served with a sweet, salty and spicy dipping sauce made from shallots, fish sauce, dried chillies, dried shrimp, and palm sugar (nam pla wan means "sweet fish sauce"). This is normally eaten as a snack on its own.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: เมี่ยงคำ
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Dried shrimp and other ingredients wrapped in cha phlu (Thai: ช้าพลู) leaves.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: เมี่ยงปลา
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Similar to Miang kham, the main ingredient for this wrap is deep-fried fish.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: หมูแดดเดียว
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Deep-fried strips of sun dried pork, here with sesame seeds. A spicy dipping sauce (very often Sriracha sauce) is almost always provided with this dish.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: เนื้อแดดเดียวกะเพราทอด
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Deep-fried strips of sun dried beef and with crispy fried holy basil.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: เนื้อเค็มทอด
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Salted, sun-dried beef that has been deep-fried before serving.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ปลาหมึกย่าง
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Grilled cuttlefish.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: สะเต๊ะ
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Marinated beef, chicken or pork grilled on bamboo skewers and usually served with nam chim sate (peanut sauce) and achat (pickled cucumber).

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ทอดมันข้าวโพด
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Deep-fried cakes made with corn and herbs in a batter, and served with a sweet chilli sauce

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ทอดมันปลา
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Deep fried patties of minced fish mixed with red curry paste, finely chopped yardlong beans (tua fak yao), and finely shredded leaves of kaffir lime (makrut). Knife fish (pla krai) is popularly used. For this variety of thot man, a sweet & hot similar to chicken chili sauce is provided usually mixed with chopped pieces of cucumber, crushed peanuts, and topped with phak chi.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ทอดมันปู
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Deep fried patties of minced crab meat. Plum sauce is commonly provided.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ทอดมันกุ้ง
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Another popular variety of thot man where minced shrimp or prawn is used. Plum sauce is commonly provided.

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ถุงทอง
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Small, crispy, deep-fried pastry purses filled with a mixture of minced chicken or pork together with minced prawns, mushroom and water chestnut, and served with sweet plum sauce or Thai sweet chilli sauce[28]

savoury_snacks_and_starters.thai_script: ตัวไหมทอด
savoury_snacks_and_starters.description: Crispy, deep-fried pupae of silkworms. This dish is most often eaten as a snack to go with drinks.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: Grass jelly is made from a herb from the mint family. It is often served with only shaved ice and brown sugar.

Dara thong or thong ek krachang (ทองเอกกระจัง) is a golden dough ball made from wheat flour, egg yolks, coconut milk and sugar, topped with a little piece of gold leaf, and decorated with sugar-coated, dry-fried watermelon seeds. Nowadays, it is often wrongly referred to as cha mongkut (จ่ามงกุฎ), which is the name of another Thai traditional sweet.

The name translates to "golden threads", it is a sweet snack or dessert of strings of egg yolk shortly boiled in sugar syrup. This, and other egg-based sweets such as sangkhaya, were introduced to the royal court of Ayutthaya by Maria Guyomar de Pinha in the 17th century CE.
Taro root mixed with flour into balls and served in coconut milk.

A multi-colored pudding of layers of sticky rice flour and tapioca flour mixed with coconut milk and sugar. Each layer will be differently scented (pandan, jasmine and more). It is similar to the Indonesian, Malaysian and Singaporean kueh lapis.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: ขนมฝรั่งกุฎีจีน
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: Small muffins. The main ingredients are duck eggs, sugar and wheat flour. No butter, milk or yeast. No preservatives. The little cakes are topped with raisins, gourds dipped in syrup, and persimmon.[29]
Small coconut hotcakes with different fillings. These are made on a special cast-iron pan with indentations. Two halves are eventually stuck to one another to form the finished mini-pancake.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: ขนมหม้อแกง
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: A sweet baked pudding containing coconut milk, eggs, palm sugar and flour, sprinkled with sweet fried onions.
The unique smoky flavor and the deep black color comes from coconut ash. It is made from a mix of sticky rice flour and tapioca flour, together with coconut milk and sugar.
Jasmine scented coconut pudding set in cups of fragrant pandan leaf.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: ขนมตะโก้เผือก
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: Traditional sweets made with coconut milk, rice, flour, sugar and boiled taro pieces in a banana leaf cone.
Palm flavoured mini cake with shredded coconut on top.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: ขนมถ้วยตะไล
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: Steamed sweet coconut jelly and cream.
These sweets are made by boiling balls of dough made from glutinous rice powder, coconut cream, grated coconut, sugar and flavourings, and then covering them with more grated coconut.
These are desserts made with an agar gelatine. The colours represent different flavours.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: ข้าวเหนียวมะม่วง
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: Sticky rice cooked in sweetened thick coconut milk, served with slices of ripe mango.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: ข้าวเหนียวสังขยา
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: Sticky rice served with an egg and coconut custard (coconut jam).

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: ข้าวต้มมัดไส้กล้วย
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: The dish is made by wrapping sweet banana and sticky rice inside a banana leaf and then steaming it. The banana takes on a pink colour after steaming.
Deep-fried bananas in a light batter
Wafers or chunks of rice candy with beans and sesame. Often prepared as an offering to the monks[30]

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: ลอดช่องน้ำกะทิ
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: Pandan-flavoured rice flour noodles in sweetened coconut milk, similar to the Indonesian cendol.
Pickled green mango is often eaten as a (semi-)sweet snack.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: โรตีกล้วยไข่
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: Sliced banana and a beaten egg are fried inside a thin sheet of dough, then cut and served with sweetened condensed milk and/or sugar.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: โรตีสายไหม
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: An extremely sweet kind of candy floss/cotton candy which is wrapped inside small, thin pancakes.
A chilled sweet snack/dessert with a mix of ingredients, such as sweetened chestnuts, jackfruit, lotus root, tapioca, and lot chong, in sweetened coconut milk.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: สังขยาฟักทอง
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: Steamed pumpkin with an egg-and-coconut custard filling, similar to the coconut jam from Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: สาคูถั่วดำ
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: Tapioca pearls and black beans (one of the vigna cultivars) with sweetened coconut milk and the flesh of a young coconut.
The Thai version of the Portuguese pastel de nata.

sweet_snacks_and_desserts.thai_script: สาคูไส้หมู
sweet_snacks_and_desserts.description: In Thailand tapioca balls with pork filling are call sakhu sai mu. Sakhu sai mu is a kind of snack which is very famous in Thailand and found at street stalls and markets. It is a dumpling which consists of a flour ball with a pork filling. Most people in Thailand eat it with khao kriap pak mo.
Thong yip is, like foi thong, made from egg yolks. The difference is that instead of being thread-like, thong yip are shaped like flowers.

drinks.description: It is made from strongly brewed black tea ("red tea" in East Asia). The tea is sweetened with sugar and served with ice.
It is made from strongly brewed black tea ("red tea" in East Asia). The tea is sweetened with sugar flavored with sugar and lime and served hot or with ice. Mint may also be added.
It is made from strongly brewed black tea ("red tea" in East Asia). The tea is sweetened with sugar and condensed milk and served hot.

It is made from strongly brewed black tea ("red tea" in East Asia). Additional ingredients may include orange blossom water, star anise, crushed tamarind seed and sometimes other spices. The tea is sweetened with sugar and condensed milk and served chilled.

Kafae boran literally translates to "ancient/traditional coffee". It is a strong coffee that is served with sweetened condensed milk, similar in taste to the kopi that is served at kopi tiam (traditional coffee shops) of Malaysia and Singapore. It is usually made with robusta coffee beans, by steeping the grounds inside a brewing "sock".
An energy drink and the origin of Red Bull.
A distilled alcohol made from glutinous rice, it is often a home-made moonshine.

drinks.thai_script: เหล้าแม่โขง
drinks.description: Closer to a rum, it is distilled from sugarcane and rice.

drinks.thai_script: น้ำใบบัวบก
drinks.description: A refreshing drink made from the leaves of the Asiatic Pennywort (Centella asiatica).

drinks.thai_script: น้ำดอกอัญชัน
drinks.description: A refreshing drink made from Clitoria ternatea flower flavored with sugar served with ice.
A refreshing drink made from lime juice flavored with sugar and a pinch of salt served with ice.

Resembling a slush puppie laced with alcohol, this drink is popular with students. Nam means liquid or water, phan is derived from the English word "punch": a beverage based on fruit and often containing alcohol.
A refreshing drink made from lemongrass. It can be served either hot or with ice.
A sweet Thai black ice coffee. The name is of Teochew origin where "o" means black, and "liang" means cold.
A Thai rum which has been distilled since 1977.
A traditional rice wine from the Isan region.
